...a picture of Robert H. Goddard's (rocketry pioneer) workshop. It's not a barn, but a workshop like that could just as easily have been set up in a barn.

Yes. Very well and good. Hell, post the 1940s images of the V2s we launched in New Mexico. Those have very barn-like structures, as well. I've never seen anyone say anything different. However, Goddard also didn't launch people (or anything else) into space.

Again, the barn makes sense iff we are launching small sounding rockets or airplanes built by bicycle mechanics. But we don't. We start with a Mercury capsule.

We start with a capsule that bears a superficial resemblance to the Mercury capsule. There's no reason to believe it's engineered to anything like the same standards, and indeed the part description suggests otherwise.

The Mercury capsule wasn't built in a fancy cleanroom because it really needed to be, it was built in a fancy cleanroom because NASA really didn't want to kill someone. Kerbals don't necessarily have the same concerns, as evidenced by the space program being happy to put a Kerbal atop their very first rocket and blast it skywards.

There's no reason to believe it's engineered to anything like the same standards, and indeed the part description suggests otherwise.

The 100% reliability with never a chance of a single failure on any part indicates otherwise. If it's shoddily built crap made out of trash...

Forget it...

The mercury capsule wasn't constructed inside the VAB anyway. It's the Vehicle Assembly Building, not the capsule assembly building. Kennedy Space Center's VAB is not a clean room.
